Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Generalized Compressive Sensing Approach to Data Acquisition and Ad-Hoc Sensor Networking

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to advance the field of compressive sensing and broaden its scope into a multitude of new applications, such as ad hoc networking, by significantly enhancing the efficiency through the utilization of problem-specific signals and systems properties. The proposed approach is to design a novel rateless-coding-inspired generalized compressive sensing (GCS) framework and to integrate it into different stages of sensing, information processing, and cross-layer designs in the network design processes.

Intellectual Merit: The proposed research bridges the gap between the advanced theoretical research on modern coding and compressive sensing, as to significantly enhance the efficiency of data acquisition and ad hoc networking. GCS offers the flexibility of exploiting problem-specific properties, such as non-uniform sparsity and non-uniform importance of data in the sensing and recovery phases. This is expected to result in a significant reduction in sensing and communication costs. Through cross-layer design of GCS and underlying network protocols, efficient data acquisition and distributed data storage problems in sensor networks will be investigated.

Broader Impacts: This proposal is expected to have a significant direct impact on advancing the theory and practice of compressive sensing and an indirect impact on many areas in which compressive sensing has potential application, such as medical imaging, hyper-spectral imaging, and bio-informatics. Furthermore, it expected to have an impact on increasing the participation of under-represented students in the PI's research group, as well as in promoting engineering education among high school students, in integration of research and education through curriculum development/revision, in training graduate students, and in promoting multidisciplinary research and collaboration through initiating ECE Seminar Day Program at OSU.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Compressive sensing (CS) is an elegant technique that enables under sampling of signals with a sparse representation in a proper basis. In this project, we advanced the field of CS and broadened its scope into a multitude of new applications by significantly enhancing the efficiency through the utilization of problem-specific signals and system properties.

We devised a generalized compressive sensing (GCS) framework to enhance the performance of the sparse signal recovery for sparse signals for which some side information beyond sparsity is available. GCS offers the flexibility of exploiting, at both sensing and recovery phases, problem-specific properties such as non-uniform sparsity and non-uniform importance of signal coefficients. Our designed CS techniques can be applied to a large category of sparse signals such as images and videos as we studied. Moreover, we integrated GCS with a learning mechanism to make it adaptive over time.

We further extended the scope of our proposed compressive sensing framework to networking applications to reduce the sensing and communication costs. We studied the integration of CS and wireless sensor networks for the efficient data acquisition and distributed data storage over a network. We showed that a cross-layer design of GCS and underlying network protocols is necessary for an optimal performance.

Over the course of this project, three PhD and several master students were trained. This project also provided the opportunity for undergraduate and underrepresented students to get involved with the research. The PI developed two new graduate-level courses and updated their contents every year based on the new research results from this project. This provided a powerful venue for the dissemination of the latest research findings and exposing the students to new research directions. The mathematical developments and the results from this project were published in leading journals and conference proceedings.
